title: MAMBO Pop Up
history: The history of the Museum of Modern Art of Bogotá - MAMBO
historyDescription: In 1953, General Gustavo Rojas Pinilla mounted a military coup, establishing a dictatorship that restricted the rights and freedoms of the citizens of Colombia. Nevertheless, during this period important steps were taken in the modernisation of the country. One of these was a decree leading to the creation of the Museum of Modern Art, signed in 1955 by a group comprising intellectuals, artists and government ministers. The Museum existed for several years without a permanent site. During this time, it occupied various venues, including the National University and the District Planetarium. The critic and administrator Marta Traba was a driving force behind opening the Museum to the public from 1962, until 1967, when she was expelled from the country for her objection to military intervention at the National University, where the Museum was then based. Gloria Zea took over as director when the Museum left the university campus, managing various sites until the acquisition in 1974, of the plot on which the present building now stands. Construction began in 1979 and was completed in 1985 (Zea, 1994, pp.50-78). Today, MAMBO is situated in the centre of the city, neighbouring both the Parque Bicentenario and the Parque de la Independencia and within easy walking distance of the District Planetarium. It is housed in a building designed by Colombian architect Rogelio Salmona, based on the principles of abstract art, and modern architecture in Bogotá (Moreno y Medina,1994, pp.88-92). MAMBO has worked for 57 years in the research, preservation and promotion of modern and contemporary art. The artist Claudia Hakim took over as director in 2016, heading a new team with aims to work with the general public on a variety of projects involving curatorship, museography, and education.
author: Oscar Monsalve
forWhatContent:
This section proposes to reflect on the value of museums, taking into account the new global definition that is still under debate and the history of the Museum of Modern Art of Bogotá  MAMBO. 

According to a recent (still being debated) definition by the International Council of Museums:

Museums are democratising, inclusive and polyphonic spaces for critical dialogue about pasts and futures. Acknowledging and addressing the conflicts and challenges of the present, they hold artefacts and specimens in trust for society, safeguard diverse memories for future generations and guarantee equal rights and equal access to heritage for all people. Museums are not for profit. They are participatory and transparent, and work in active partnership with and for diverse communities to collect, preserve, research, interpret, exhibit, and enhance understandings of the world, aiming to contribute to human dignity and social justice, global equality and planetary wellbeing. (Icom, 2019)

keyConcepts.title: Curatorship
keyConcepts.content: The practice of selecting and organising a series of artworks into an exhibition according to a predefined thematic framework.

keyConcepts.title: Museography
keyConcepts.content: Discipline dealing with development of techniques and methods in the running of a museum, primarily the architectural and spatial features of temporary exhibitions and permanent collection.

img.alt: Oscar Monsalve. Installing ‘Yellows and Reds’, by Pedro Ramos for the VII Athens Salon. 1981. Source: MAMBO archive.

keyConcepts.title: Cultural Heritage
keyConcepts.content: A set of tangible and intangible attributes making up the memory and identity of a human group, and which has a symbolic, historic and economic value.

img.alt: Oscar Monsalve. Third floor of present building under construction. 1983. Source: MAMBO archive.

keyConcepts.title: Collection
keyConcepts.content: A set of material products of a culture forming part of an institution dedicated to the preservation of its heritage. In museums of anthropology these may be objects such as tools and clothing; in art museums, paintings and sculptures.

keyConcepts.content: A system of government by the entire population of a state, where decisions are taken collectively and which seeks the guaranteed participation of the majority.

title: Modern Art in the world.
historyDescription: Modern Art was a process during which painters, sculptors and writers sought out novel forms of representation. The modern period in art is usually described as occurring between 1850 – 1970. The industrial revolutions of nineteenth century Europe and the violent upheavals inspired by the 1789 Revolution in France, all contributed to the modern movement. Artists rebelled against academic art with its Renaissance preoccupations; religion, Greek mythology, and the traditional genres of portrait and still life, preferring to explore individual interests and problems in their work (Gallerix, 2009). In the 1830s the invention of photography caused a break with the tradition of figurative representation and led artists to create work according to a personal aesthetic. The work of the European vanguards exemplifies formal and conceptual explorations made by artists of this period as they experimented with new subjects, materials, techniques and processes, pushing the boundaries of what was understood as “art”. (Academia Play, 2016).
author: Edouard Manet
forWhatContent: This section proposes to reflect on the rebellious roots of modern art.
didYouKnow: Did you know the advent of photography radically altered the way we see the world. It brought about great changes in the image-making process and the materiality of works of art.
questions: Why was it important for the artists of the time to question classical ideals of beauty?
Why does a creative artist need to rebel and ask questions?
Why do we need areas where we can use our right to free expression?

keyConcepts.title: Academic art
keyConcepts.content: Artistic current emerging from the Paris Academy of Fine Arts at the start of the nineteenth century and which looks back to art of the classical period. Also known as Neoclassicism; it is a romantic and idealist movement, linking art to ideas of beauty, perfection and technical skill.

img.alt: Ricardo Acevedo Bernal. Model in Paris, 1889. Source: MAMBO Collection.

keyConcepts.title: Vanguards
keyConcepts.content: Early twentieth century antiacademic and experimental art movements, emerging out of the First World War and its aftermath. Cubism, Dadaism and Futurism all influenced the birth of modern art.

img.alt: Salvador Dalí. Venus of the Head of Roses. Undated. Source MAMBO Collection.

keyConcepts.title: Abstract Art
keyConcepts.content: Refers to artworks that do not represent any part of their subjects in a precise way.

img.alt: Amelia Peláez. Untitled, 1967. Source: MAMBO Collection.

keyConcepts.title: Figurative Art
keyConcepts.content: Refers to artworks that represent images, objects and scenes from life in a realistic and recognisable way.

img.alt: Liliana Porter. Tear. 1974. Source: MAMBO Collection.

img1.caption: Édouard Manet (Paris, France, 1832-1883). Forerunner of impressionism and modern painting. This painting caused controversy for its depiction of a nude woman who appears to be a sex worker, challenging contemporary morality and traditional portrayals of the nude in art.

img2.caption: Camille Claudel (Fère-en-Tardenois, France, 1864-1943). One of the pioneers of modern sculpture in her opposition to the French Academy. In this highly symbolic work, Claudel shows her interest in themes other than the canonical glorification of beauty and perfection.

img3.alt: Pablo Picasso. Les Demoiselles d’Avignon. 1907. Oil on Canvas. Source: Wikimedia Commons under licence C.C. BY 2.0. Collection of New York Museum of Modern Art (Moma).
img3.caption: Pablo Picasso (Malaga, Spain, 1881-1973). Probably the most celebrated of all modern artists for his defiance of form and use of distortion. The iconic work, Les Demosielles d’Avignon, was the first painting to feature physical distortion and geometric abstraction as a new procedure in painting, qualities which would later develop into Cubism.

title: Modern Art in Colombia
historyDescription: In Colombia, the first examples of modernist painting start to appear during the early years of the twentieth century. Artists taking on the legacy of Dadaism and cubism searched for new forms in painting and sculpture as an escape from the traditional aesthetic of beauty. Colombia was also a scenario for the global debate between capitalism and communism, and the drive for change led artists to question established moral principles in politically transgressive artworks. A desire to uncouple Colombian art history from the European tradition, inspired the “Bachué” group of artists to explore the imagery and symbols of local indigenous and rural communities. From the 1950s onwards, influenced by political events such as El Bogotazo, artists adopted a firm political stance, clearly seen in the confrontation between the defenders of socialist realism and the maintenance of a separate identity, and the supporters of abstract expressionism. This clash between abstraction and figurative art had a decisive influence on the origins of contemporary art in the country (Jaramillo, 2012, pp. 129-206).
author: Beatriz Daza
forWhatContent: This section proposes to reflect on the relationship between the political context and art, and the need to construct national discourses in the face of foreign influences.
didYouKnow: Did you know the period of fighting between Liberals and Conservatives in Colombia, known as La Violencia, drove artists to protest against the social and political situation.
activity: Research your own family tree, pinpoint your family origins and facial features. Draw a face or design a logo to represent your family, and explain why.
questions: What are the ideological differences between socialist realism and abstract expressionism?
How would you define national identity? What modern and traditional values do you see in your own family?
Since not everyone shares the same morals, beliefs and values, how do we arrive at a consensus and avoid violence?

keyConcepts.title: Cold War
keyConcepts.content: Political, military and cultural confrontation lasting from 1945 – 1989 between capitalist Western powers, led by the United States, and communist Soviet Union.

img.alt: Unknown author. Photograph of the Berlin Wall. 1989. Source: Wikimedia Commons under GNU licence.

keyConcepts.title: El Bogotazo
keyConcepts.content: Eruption of rioting and violence in Bogota, triggered by the assassination of presidential candidate Jorge Eliécer Gaitán on 9 April 1948, giving rise to the period of fighting between Liberal and Conservative parties known as La Violencia.

img.alt: Sady González. Burning Tram. 1948. Source: MAMBO Collection.

keyConcepts.title: Socialist Realism
keyConcepts.content: Artistic style developed in the Soviet Union during the 1920s, aimed at an ideologically motivated representation of reality, often with the intention of denouncing supposed anti-Soviet tendencies. Influential in the creation of Latin American movements, for whom socialist realism was a weapon in the fight against imperialism.

img.alt: Unknown author. Monument to combatants in the October Revolution. Almaty, Kasakhstan. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public licence.

keyConcepts.title: North American Expressionism (Abstract Expressionism)
keyConcepts.content: Considered USA’s first abstract art movement. Pictorial works on large canvases onto which paint has been spattered in a spontaneous manner, creating free, expressive images. Abstract expressionism stood in opposition to socialist realism, and was used during the Cold War to propagate ideas associated with capitalism.

img.alt: Jackson Pollock. Head. 1938-1941. Source: Wikimedia Commons under licence CC BY 2.0.

keyConcepts.title: Communism
keyConcepts.content: Economic system proposed by Karl Marx; in which private property is eliminated and goods produced by the workers are distributed equally, and where the state controls the means of production.

img.alt: John Jabez Edwin Mayall. Portrait of Karl Marx. 1875. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public licence.

keyConcepts.title: Capitalism
keyConcepts.content: Economic system put forward by Adam Smith; in which capital generated through workers’ labour belongs to an individual or private company, driving a market economy and creating socio-economic division.

img.alt: Unknown Author. Portrait of Adam Smith. 1800. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public licence.

img1.alt: Beatriz Daza. Two Yellow Days. 1966. Source: MAMBO Collection.
img1.caption: Beatriz Daza (Pamplona, Colombia, 1927-1968) was a ceramist and painter, pioneer of assemblages and experimentation in the use of the canvas as support for a variety of objects. This work is one of her representations of domestic spaces as fragmented still-life composition.

img2.alt: Alejandro Obregón. Violence. 1962. Obregón. Hernán Díaz. Source: MAMBO Collection.
img2.caption: Alejandro Obregón (Barcelona, Spain, 1920-1992), came to this country at the age of six. He was a member of the Barranquilla Group and an important figure in Colombian modern and contemporary painting. He combines figuration and abstraction in his paintings (figurative expressionism), which display expressive brushstrokes and patches of colour. This work shows Obregón’s preoccupation with denouncing harsh realities in Colombia.

img3.alt: Edgar Negret. Face of Christ. 1949. MAMBO Collection.
img3.caption: Edgar Negret (Popayán, Colombia, 1920-2012). One of Colombia’s most influential sculptors. By incorporating materials denoting modernity into his work such as iron, aluminium and wood, he brings into question ideas of the industrial and the natural. This piece represents a figure from Colombian religious culture, but in an abstract manner.

title: Conceptual Art in the world
historyDescription: Conceptual Art (also known as Conceptualism), has its beginnings during the 1960s and consists in recognising art not only for its aesthetic qualities, but also for its intellectual significance. Conceptual art does not use one medium in particular, as it does not rely on form, but on content and the ability to communicate an idea. For this reason, it may take different forms: installation, photography, readymade, performance, graphic work or video art. Conceptual artists are interested in context. They take a theme and confer new meanings on objects, images and concepts through their work. With Land Art for example, an interest in space has led artists to alter the landscape and make use of available materials. Minimalism, on the other hand, makes no attempt to represent an outside reality, “what you see is what you see” (Tate, s. f.). During the 1960s and 1970s great social changes were brought about through activism on the part of various movements: Feminist, LGBT, and antiracist movements, protests against the Vietnam War and the May 1968 demonstrations in Paris. Conceptual art often pinpoints and denounces social, political, religious or ecological problems, with frequent use of irony and satire. It also questions the significance of art itself, asserting that what is “art” is subjectively determined by the artist themselves, while the spectator completes the work with their own interpretation (EcuRed, 2019).
author: Cildo Merireles
forWhatContent: This section proposes to reflect on art as intellectual process.
didYouKnow: Did you know Marcel Duchamp created one of the first works of conceptual art in 1917, when he entered a porcelain urinal into a gallery exhibition.
questions: What is the significance of content over form?
In your opinion, what is and is not art?
What research methods do artists use?
proposal: This section proposes to reflect on art as intellectual process.

keyConcepts.title: Counterculture
keyConcepts.content: Counterculture refers to values and modes of behaviour that are opposed to those established by a society. The term first appears in a 1968 book by historian Theodore Roszak, who uses “counterculture” to describe the beat generation, the hippie movement, the sexual revolution and the pacifist movements of the United States.

img.alt: Mark Goff. Woodstock Festival opening ceremony. 1969. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public licence.

keyConcepts.title: Context
keyConcepts.content: Array of physical, sociopolitical and cultural conditions surrounding an object or event. Context determines the purpose, customs and values of a particular human group.

img.alt: Carlos Caicedo. Bogotá, 1975. Source: MAMBO collection.

keyConcepts.title: Aesthetics
keyConcepts.content: A philosophical discipline that studies the perception, sensations and criteria involved in our judgement of beauty and taste in art.

img.alt: Francisco Antonio Cano. Still Life. 1912. Source: MAMBO Collection.

img1.alt: Cildo Meireles. Zero Cruzeiro. 1974. Source: MAMBO Collection.
img1.caption: Cildo Meireles (Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 1948) is an artist recognised for his contribution to conceptual art in Latin America, through works based on an analysis of Latin American political and economic systems. Here he uses a series of fake Brazilian banknotes to generate reflection around capital, power, and exploitation.

img2.alt: Andy Warhol. Campbell's Soup Cans. 1962. Special edition. 2015. Source: Wikimedia Commons under Creative Commons licence Attribution 3.0 Unported.
img2.caption: Andy Warhol (Pittsburg, USA, 1928-1987) was one of the pioneers of Pop Art in the United States. Warhol used grocery products to reflect on consumerism and originality in art. In this well-known work, the artist copied the packaging of a product of mass consumption. He then reproduced it, marking consumerism as a contemporary way of life, and posing the question: can any object be considered art?

title: Conceptual Art in Colombia
historyDescription: During this time, Colombia, like most Latin American countries experienced social and political unrest, reflected in the period known as the Frente Nacional. This period of restricted freedoms began with the 1953 Military Coup of Gustavo Rojas Pinilla and lasted for 16 years. Conceptual art in Colombia evolved out of reaction to despotism prevalent in political and artistic institutions, under which artists, like Feliza Bursztyn, were persecuted and forced to leave the country. Conceptual artists in Colombia experimented with new media and formats, combining artistic disciplines such as the readymade, photography, and installation, among others. Artistic collectives, such as El Sindicato were formed, which challenged individualism and put forward new ideas about society in their manifestos (Barrios, 1999). Means of reproduction such as photocopy and screen-printing helped democratise art and move it away from official spheres. The Salón Nacional de Artistas sparked debates and controversy revealing artists’ desire to break away from this institution. The Salón did not recognise conceptual art until 1978, when it awarded first prize to “A-la-cena con Zapatos” (Dinner with Shoes) by El Sindicato. (Herrera, 2011)
author: Feliza Bursztyn
forWhatContent: This section proposes to reflect on the relationship between 60s and 70s Counterculture and new forms of artistic expression in Colombia.
didYouKnow: Did you one of the first pieces of performance art in Colombia occurred when a group of artists unhooked their paintings from the wall in the Salón Nacional de Artistas, and set fire to several coffins in the centre of Bogotá.
activity: Develop a work of conceptual art where you capture a problem from your local context.
questions: How is democracy reflected in art?
What elements of historical context do you recognise in a work of art?

gallery.alt: Bernardo Salcedo. What Dante did not know, Beatriz loved birth control. 1966. Source: MAMBO Collection
gallery.caption: Bernardo Salcedo (Bogotá, Colombia, 1939-2007) was one of the pioneers of conceptual art in Colombia. He worked combining elements of painting, writing, and sculpture to generate questions about the socio-historical context. This work arises as a tribute to the life of Dante Alighieri and his muse Beatriz Portinari, with whom he never consummated his love. This work was awarded for reflecting the new proposals of conceptual art with the use of minimalist volumes and irony in his name.

keyConcepts.title: Coup d’Etat
keyConcepts.content: Civil or military overthrow of a democratically elected government. In Colombia, the military regime of Gustavo Rojas Pinilla was installed following a coup against conservative president Laureano Gómez. This regime was characterised by curtailment of rights and civil liberties and the implementation of important projects for the infrastructure of the country.

img.alt: Unknown author. Portrait of Gustavo Rojas Pinilla. S,f. Source: Wikimedia Commons under licence CC BY SA 4.0.

keyConcepts.title: National Front
keyConcepts.content: Period of restricted democracy lasting from 1957 – 1974 during which Liberal and Conservative parties took turns in the presidency. The origin of the armed conflict is traced back to this period, due to the exclusion of socialist ideas from the political scene.

img.alt: Semana Magazine. General Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, President of Colombia, surrounded by his cabinet. 1956. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public licence.

keyConcepts.title: National Salon of Artists
keyConcepts.content: Annual exhibition inaugurated in 1940 by then Education Minister Jorge Eliécer Gaitán and president Eduardo Santos. Prizes were awarded to outstanding artists, and the event was a platform for exhibition and national debate. The Salón provides a record of the most important ideas in modern and contemporary art over the following decades.

img.alt: José Hernán Aguilar. Salón Atenas vs Salón Nacional in Re-Vista of Latin American Art and Architecture (Medellín, Colombia) - Vol. 2 no. 6, pp. 17-21, 1981. Courtesy of Familia Sierra Maya.

img1.alt: Feliza Bursztyn. Cuja. 1972. Source: MAMBO Collection
img1.caption: Feliza Bursztyn (Bogotá, Colombia, 1933-1982) is considered the pioneer of installation in Colombia. A controversial and transgressive artist, she defied artistic convention in her sculptural work, using materials such as scrap iron, aluminium waste and engine parts. She also made use of sound and movement. Her series of bed-sculptures draped with shiny material appear to contain bodies in movement during the sexual act. With this, Feliza sought to stage a private and intimate moment and bring it out into the public space. She creates an atmosphere of eroticism and enfolds the spectator in an experience both moving and sensual

img2.alt: Jonier Marín. Paper and Pencil. 1976. Source: MAMBO Collection.
img2.caption: Jonier Marín (Argelia, Colombia, 1946) calls into question traditional artistic processes, and here creates a work that asks the question: who decides what is art? 'Without wasting any time, I asked artists whom I met while travelling to draw anything they wanted on a piece of paper, and to attach their portrait to the drawing, thus validating the work.' Jonier Marín.

img3.alt: Álvaro Barrios. The Great Plexi. 1979. Source: MAMBO Collection.
img3.caption: Álvaro Barrios (Cartagena, Colombia, 1945) is an artist from the Colombian Caribbean who displays an interest in conceptualism, creating readymades and appropriations of popular graphics. In this work he alludes to the work of Marcel Duchamp; Barrios uses plexiglass and incorporates a series of letters, notes and photographs exchanged between the artist and one of his friends.

title: Contemporary Art in the world
historyDescription: The emergence of contemporary art in the second half of the twentieth century is characterised by a variety of theoretical and technical approaches. Contemporary artists take art practice to its limits and seek to generate critical reflection in the observer through their enquiries. Artists embrace other fields of knowledge in a transdisciplinary manner. Globalisation and internet access permit expansion of new technologies, the screen affording the public a new and greater proximity to the image (Ampudia, 2016). The incursion of technology and new media brings diverse possibilities for the relationship between artworks, artist and public, frequently resulting in offerings that are in interactive and relational, such as the happening and the performance. In contemporary art, the spectator is often required to step up and participate in the work, giving them the opportunity to immerse themselves in multi-sensory environments (Pazos, 2018).
author: Damien Hirst
forWhatContent: This section proposes to reflect on transdisciplinarity in art, use of technology and the possibilities of spectator interaction.
didYouKnow: Did you know the international art market has recently expanded as an investment opportunity, with work by sought-after artists selling to the highest bidder and circulating between private collectors and museums.
questions: What possibilities are implied by the transdisciplinary approach to art?
How does technology affect our relationship with the world around us?
What opportunities are offered by works involving the spectator?

gallery.caption: Kara Walker (Stockton, United States, 1969 ) is an Afro artist who has dabbled in drawing, collage, installation and film since the 1960s. Her work is set in the pre-American civil war era, she uses characters built with silhouettes, questions notions of race, gender and identity. This work made with sugar known as “sugar mammy” is a reflection on racism and colonization.

gallery.caption: Marina Abramovic (Belgrade, Serbia, 1946) is an artist known for being a forerunner of performance, and throughout her life she proposed different artistic actions that tended to involve the public, questioning the limits between art and life. This work proposes a very simple action: look into the viewer's eyes for as long as he or she decides. This performance invites the public to participate through silence and gaze, creating an intimate and deep space in the museum.

title: Contemporary Art in Colombia
historyDescription: From the 1950s onwards, Colombia underwent significant social change marked by rapid urban growth due to internal displacement and modernisation. New ways of representing the urban landscape were a recurrent theme for artists such as Fernell Franco, Carlos Caicedo and Dora Franco, who used photography in an artistic manner, connecting with other areas of visual production such as design, publicity, popular graphics, and the media. Struggles for rights and gender equality drove the creation of works centred around the body, homoerotism and sexuality, with art becoming a space for free expression. María Evelia Marmolejo, Luis Caballero and Karen Lamassonne all created work based around their gender identity, combining techniques such as drawing, video and performance. Social and political tensions during the 60s and 70s prompted art that dared call into question national, religious and cultural symbols; as reflected in the work of Antonio Caro and Bernardo Salcedo (Jaramillo, Suarez and Wills, 2018). The Museum of Modern Art of Bogota MAMBO joined with the Modern Art Museums of Medellín, Cali y Barranquilla in highlighting artists of different regions. Two decisive events for contemporary art in Colombia took place at the MAMBO: the exhibition Espacios Ambientales (Environmental Spaces), which brought the installation to Colombia; and the Salones Atenas, which reinforced the country’s burgeoning contemporary art movement (Jaramillo, 2012).
author: Beatriz González
forWhat: An art for the here and now?
forWhatContent: This section proposes to reflect on the forms of expression used in contemporary art and the role played by contemporary artists in Colombia.
didYouKnow: Did you know that in the Constitution of 1991, the Colombian State acknowledges its duty to support the right of all citizens to access art and culture, as a guarantee of the right to freedom of expression.
activity: You have reached the end of your journey from modern art in the world to contemporary art in Colombia. You now have the creative tools to create a work of art. Make a proposal for an artwork of your own about an issue that concerns you. Use the materials you have at hand.
questions: How has art influenced the history of Colombia?
What topics will you explore in your own art?

gallery.alt: Catalina Mejía. Roses and thorns. 2011. Mixed on canvas. Source: MAMBO Collection.
gallery.caption: Catalina Mejía (Bogotá, Colombia, 1962 ) is a representative artist of contemporary painting in Colombia. She has experimented with collage, proposing enigmatic images with nostalgic atmospheres through the use of light. This work shows the simplicity and sensitivity of the artist, between the figurative and the Abstract gives us a deep and dramatic feeling.

gallery.alt: Juan Manuel Echavarría. Requiem NN. 2006-2015. Source: MAMBO Collection.
gallery.caption: Juan Manuel Echavarría (Medellín, Colombia, 1947) is an artist who has been exploring the different territories of the country in search of the trace of the armed conflict since the 1990s, through photography and video recording scenes where acts of violence occurred to preserve his memory and generate a poetic view of reality. This work consists of photographs of the tombstones of a cemetery on the banks of the Magdalena River where the bodies of the NN dumped downstream have been buried.

keyConcepts.title: New media
keyConcepts.content: Techniques and approaches in contemporary art such as the readymade, video, performance and installation, among others, which broadened traditional concepts of artistic creation as grounded in drawing, painting and sculpture.

keyConcepts.title: Armed Conflict in Colombia
keyConcepts.content: Armed confrontation numbering over eight million victims: emerging during the 1960s with the founding of guerrilla group Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC-EP), concluding with the peace treaty signed in 2016 during the presidency of Manuel Santos. Although the treaty put an end to decades of conflict, violence continues in some regions of the country.

keyConcepts.title: Constitution of 1991
keyConcepts.content: The Constituent National Assembly of 1991 arose out of the treaty between the government of Belisario Betancur and guerilla organization, M-19. It was during this Assembly that the political constitution of Colombia was drafted. This document cemented the democratic running of the country.

In her work she explores the divide between painting and sculpture, inserting images from popular culture into everyday objects to communicate ideas around the Colombian context, gender and landscape. In this work, the artist intervenes in a wooden bed with a religious image.

This artist has explored different formats and materials, including video and photography in creating work whose design incorporates both space and time. In this series, consisting of shower curtains with the outlines of human bodies drawn onto them, the artist considers intimacy and absence.
